channel.title: WSJ.com: World News
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Cargo Plane Accident Kills Two in Hong Kong
item.description: The accident involved a Boeing 747-400 cargo aircraft that had departed from Dubai’s Al Maktoum International Airport.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Cheng

item.title: China’s Economy Expands at Slowest Pace in a Year
item.description: China said its economy grew 4.8% in the third quarter, a deceleration that nonetheless keeps it on track to hit its official annual target.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: A Ukrainian City Fights to Keep the Power On
item.description: As Ukrainians prepare for their fifth winter at war, the struggle in Chernihiv to cope with darkness and keep power flowing is a portent for cities throughout the country.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: How China Took Over the World’s Rare-Earths Industry
item.description: Beijing used bare-knuckle tactics in a multidecade effort to consolidate control over supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jon Emont

item.title: Bolivia Elects Pro-Market President After Two Decades of Socialist Rule
item.description: The election of Rodrigo Paz marks a sharp turn for Bolivia, which will seek closer ties to the U.S. and lithium investments.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: Trump Turns Up Heat on Latin America
item.description: Attacks in the Caribbean, aid cuts for Colombia and pressure on Venezuela’s Maduro have blurred the lines between counternarcotics and regime change.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Opinion | An English City Bars Israeli Soccer Fans
item.description: Birmingham bans them from a match, rather than police Islamist radicals.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | The Other Side of the Gaza Hostage Deal
item.description: Released terrorists received millions in ‘pay for slay’ PA salaries.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Is Cutting Aid to Colombia Over Drugs
item.description: President says Colombian leader hasn’t moved to stop drug production.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Opinion | Did Brazil Penetrate U.S. Border Protection?
item.description: CBP admits error but continues to evade accountability in the Filipe Martins case.
item.dc:creator: Mary Anastasia O’Grady

item.title: Opinion | A Napoleonic Smash-and-Grab
item.description: Thieves target the Louvre in Paris and snatch treasures from the emperor’s era.
item.dc:creator: Brenda Cronin

item.title: Brazen Heist at Louvre Museum Snatches Priceless Royal Jewels
item.description: Thieves used a truck-mounted furniture elevator to reach the gallery housing the artifacts at the Paris museum and then fled on motorcycles, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Sam Schechner

item.title: Israel Hits Dozens of Targets in Gaza After Saying Hamas Killed Troops in Attack
item.description: Israel accused the militant group of violating the truce, while Hamas’s armed wing denied mounting any attack on Israeli troops.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: The Israeli Politician Who Became Netanyahu’s Top Trump Whisperer
item.description: Ron Dermer built up ties to the Republican Party that culminated in Trump supporting the war and cutting a deal to end it on Israel’s terms.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: U.S. to Repatriate Survivors of Strike on Suspected Drug Vessel
item.description: The two survivors from the latest attack will be sent to Colombia and Ecuador, avoiding a potentially thorny legal process in U.S. courts.
item.dc:creator: Shelby Holliday

item.title: A New Challenge for China’s Economy: ‘Involution’
item.description: Beijing is fighting to limit the damage from a pattern of price wars and excess capacity across multiple industries.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: U.S. Warns Hamas Against Attacks in Gaza as Pressure on Cease-Fire Deal Builds
item.description: Israel has targeted militants and others who approach its troops, as President Trump’s deal faces new challenges.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: How Venezuela’s Maduro Became Coup-Proof After Years of Military Purges
item.description: Even with U.S. warships offshore, the strongman has prevailed in efforts to unseat him—purging, spying and paying off officers so the armed forces remain loyal.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: Drone Threats Ignite Burst of Counterdrone Wizardry
item.description: Startups from Silicon Valley to Europe and beyond are racing to develop cheap, reliable systems to counter hostile drones.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Michaels

item.title: Trump’s Middle East Peace Plan Hits an Early Snag in Gaza
item.description: The unexpected dispute over Hamas’s return of dead hostages to Israel highlights the fragility of the deal.
item.dc:creator: Feliz Solomon

item.title: Trump Bets Personal Diplomacy Will Break Ukraine War Logjam
item.description: Trump’s team is preparing for another summit with Russia’s Vladimir Putin, to be held in Hungary in coming weeks, with more advance meetings and diplomatic leverage than preceded the Alaska summit earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Annie Linskey

item.title: A Family’s Odyssey to Find Somewhere Safe in Gaza
item.description: Nearly two million people fled their homes. Now Ghaidaa Qudaih and her husband and daughter are trying to find their way home.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Kiss

item.title: How a Handyman’s Wife Helped an Hermès Heir Discover He’d Lost $15 Billion
item.description: Nicolas Puech says his wealth manager isolated him from friends and family and siphoned away a massive fortune. Then came the clue that began to reveal the deception.
item.dc:creator: Nick Kostov

item.title: Trump Says He Would Rather End War Than Send Tomahawks to Ukraine
item.description: The president said he hoped Ukraine wouldn’t need the U.S. to provide it with long-range Tomahawk cruise missiles as he met with President Volodymyr Zelensky at the White House.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: U.S. Is Holding Survivors of Latest Strike Against Alleged Drug Boat
item.description: The U.S. is treating survivors from the latest attack on a suspected drug vessel in the Caribbean, according to two officials familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Opinion | The U.N. Blinks on Its Carbon Tax
item.description: Leaders delay a vote on its taxation-without-representation scheme.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Give Ukraine the Tomahawks, Mr. President
item.description: Long-range cruise missiles could be a force for peace by altering Vladimir Putin’s capacity to carry on his grinding war.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Prince Andrew Loses ‘Duke of York’ Title After Epstein Scandal
item.description: The prince agrees to forgo use of his royal title after pressure from Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Green Shipping Plan Is Delayed After Trump Backlash
item.description: Proposal for shipowners to pay a fee for their carbon emissions had been criticized by the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Costas Paris

item.title: The Attempted Assassination of a Russian Dissident Is Foiled in France
item.description: The alleged plot targeted Vladimir Osechkin, a human-rights activist in exile and a critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: Poland Frees Nord Stream Suspect, Defying Germany
item.description: It was the latest twist in a case that has stoked tension over the prosecution of suspects seen as aiding Ukraine in its fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Bojan Pancevski

item.title: Decision to Bar Israeli Fans From U.K. Soccer Match Sparks Outcry
item.description: Fans of Maccabi Tel Aviv have been told not to attend an Aston Villa game following concerns by police about violence. Authorities are now reviewing the decision.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Dangoor

item.title: At the Center of Hamas’s Fight With Its Gaza Rivals: A Hospital Hideout
item.description: Heavily armed Hamas fighters have re-established control over a hospital complex that residents and Israel’s military said was a redoubt for the group.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: Xi Removes China’s No. 2 General in Escalating Purge of Military Leadership
item.description: China also ousted eight other high-ranking military commanders, as leader Xi Jinping dials up a crackdown on corruption and disloyalty in the armed forces.
item.dc:creator: Chun Han Wong

item.title: China’s Communist Elites Gather to Map Strategy
item.description: A communique after the Communist Party’s Central Committee meeting, which runs Monday to Thursday, will indicate how Beijing aims to steer the economy through turbulence, though details of its 15th five-year plan won’t be released until March.

item.title: The Man Threatening Viktor Orbán’s 15-Year Grip on Hungary
item.description: A former ally of the authoritarian prime minister is leading in the polls as an election with huge implications for Europe and the war in Ukraine looms.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Venezuela Mobilizes Troops and Militias as U.S. Military Looms Offshore
item.description: Nicolás Maduro says his country is ready for combat, though the strongman’s military is underfunded, ill-trained and no match for American firepower.
item.dc:creator: Lara Seligman

item.title: Trump Organization Expands in India, Where Many of Its Partners Face Accusations
item.description: Indian real-estate firms have been accused of fraud, money laundering and more on other projects. The Trumps have stepped up overseas deals in the president’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grant

item.title: Trump Says He Will Meet With Putin in Budapest to Discuss End to Ukraine War
item.description: A phone conversation between the two leaders took place a day before Trump is expected to meet with Ukrainian President Zelensky.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: India Delicately Counters Trump Claim It Will Drop Russian Oil
item.description: New Delhi didn’t outright contradict the president, saying it was committed to protecting consumers by diversifying its energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: The Chinese Spy Scandal That Is Rocking Britain’s Government
item.description: When a British parliamentary researcher was arrested for allegedly spying for China, security officials expected a slam-dunk case. Instead, the trial collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Why Finding All the Bodies of the Gaza Hostages Is So Hard
item.description: Israel and other countries have established an international task force to search for missing hostage bodies in the enclave’s ruins.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: Milei’s Radical Overhaul of Argentina Meets Its Match in the Humble Peso
item.description: The Argentine president is asking for billions of dollars from the Trump administration to prop up the country’s currency, a departure from his program of free-market revisions of its economy.
item.dc:creator: Silvina Frydlewsky

item.title: American Bankers Are Making a Mint Helping China Inc. Go Global
item.description: The unlikely U.S.-China collaboration is producing frothy markets in Hong Kong, the place where Wall Street and China Inc. meet for mutual profit.
item.dc:creator: Rory Jones

item.title: Lower U.S. Tariffs Would Boost India Growth Outlook, Says Central Bank Chief
item.description: Sanjay Malhotra said talks are under way to lower tariffs, and success would help lift the economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China’s Deflationary Pressures Ease Slightly
item.description: Downward price pressures eased in September, but not quite as much as expected, as Beijing ramps up efforts to curb excess capacity and bolster domestic demand.

item.title: China, Betting It Can Win a Trade War, Is Playing Hardball With Trump
item.description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping thinks the president will fold before launching new tariffs that would roil markets.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: After Israeli Withdrawal, Hamas Launches Violent Crackdown on Rivals in Gaza
item.description: Firefights and public executions have spread fear and raised concerns about a spiral of internecine violence. “I could hear gunfire all around.”
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: As Israel’s Hostages Came Home, a Mother From Nepal Learned Her Son Would Not
item.description: Bipin Joshi was taken alive in the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks on Israel. But as other hostages were released to jubilant homecomings this week, Joshi’s family learned that he didn’t survive captivity.
item.dc:creator: Joe Parkinson

item.title: China’s Rare-Earth Export Controls Are ‘Critical Concern’ for EU, Trade Chief Says
item.description: Maros Sefcovic said the measures were causing a lot of problems for European companies, as tensions continue to rise between Brussels and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: Melania Trump Says ‘Back Channel’ With Putin Led to Return of Ukrainian Children
item.description: The first lady said she has been in contact with the Russian leader since sending him a letter in August expressing concern for abducted children.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: Microsoft, Anthropic Hire Former British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak
item.description: Sunak, who remains a member of Britain’s parliament, said he would be working with the tech companies as a senior adviser and strategic consultant.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Look

item.title: Putin Admits Russia’s Role in Downing Azerbaijani Passenger Jet
item.description: The incident last year further eroded Moscow’s influence across the former Soviet states.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: BOE Must Keep Key Rate Restrictive to Boost Growth, Mann Says
item.description: The Bank of England should keep its key rate high so as to foster conditions for future growth, rate-setter Catherine L. Mann said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Cash-Strapped U.K. Discovers Missing $4 Billion Thanks to Data Flub
item.description: Even after the revision, public borrowing is above projections made earlier this year by the government’s budget watchdog.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: International Criminal Court Convicts Sudanese Militia Leader of War Crimes
item.description: The guilty finding is a rare conviction for the court, and comes as the institution confronts U.S. sanctions and sexual-assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Dalton

item.title: Trump Praises Putin’s Offer to Extend Nuclear Treaty
item.description: An accord capping the number of long-range nuclear weapons was due to expire in February but would be extended by a year.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: German Firm’s African Green-Energy Project Runs Into Ghosts From Past
item.description: Namibia’s indigenous Nama population argues they have been sidelined in a $10 billion project being built on their ancestral lands.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kimeu

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Kills at Least 69 People in Central Philippines
item.description: The Philippines sits in the so-called Ring of Fire, a seismic arc of volcanoes and fault lines around the Pacific basin.
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Steinhauser

item.title: Russia’s Ambitious Plans in Africa Are Unraveling
item.description: Not long ago a rising military force in Africa, Russia is now struggling to maintain its footprint on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Rwanda’s President Turns to Sport to Give Tarnished Image a Makeover
item.description: Paul Kagame hopes to bring Formula One to a country accused of using rebels to take critical minerals from its neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: The Path to the American Dream Is Narrowing for Indian Tech Workers
item.description: About 70% of H-1B visas go to Indians. Looming changes to the program are upending plans, but may help India retain talent.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: The Race Back to America for a Plane Full of H-1B Workers
item.description: Reports of a new visa fee for foreign workers prompted hasty goodbyes, races to the airport and an anxiety-filled flight to San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Robert McMillan

item.title: Setting Up a Business in India Is Hard. Leaving Is Even Harder.
item.description: General Motors ran into barriers on its way out of India, highlighting the hurdles that keep foreign companies leery of doing business there.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Selinger

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.
item.dc:creator: Sal Vaglica

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.
item.dc:creator: Sarah E. Needleman

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: New Zealand’s Economy Emerges From Recession in First Quarter
item.description: New Zealand’s farm-rich economy returned to growth in the first quarter, exiting the recession that has dogged it for much of last year, but further weakness can’t be ruled out.
item.dc:creator: Rthvika Suvarna
